stream_context.summary: Returning to Twitch via a multi-stream setup, Kaze works on the 'Board the Platforms' retro level for Return to Yoshi's Island. The stream covers his creative process for designing and implementing the stage's complex 3D background, blocking out the platforming gameplay, and live-coding adjustments to the game's camera based on viewer feedback.

development_findings.summary: Kaze solved a complex visual design problem by abandoning his initial idea of using many individual 3D objects for a background and instead conceived a method of 'cutting out' shapes from a large, textured sphere to create a custom skybox.
development_findings.quote: I have THE idea. The best one yet. You have chat on screen now? Next level streams? Yep, because of Twitch and YouTube multistream. Okay. We will make a UV sphere... We're just gonna draw the shapes onto here.

development_findings.summary: In response to viewer feedback, Kaze live-adjusted the game's camera control code, attempting to balance the need for small, precise adjustments with the desire for a user-friendly rotation option for less experienced players.
development_findings.quote: By making it have a bit of a velocity, you can do a minimal adjustment like this, but you can also use this as your main camera button. That's what I want, honestly.

development_findings.summary: Kaze uses the 'block out' technique for level design, creating the level's platforming layout with simple shapes to test the gameplay flow before committing to detailed art.
Future main level themes being considered are Wild West Valley, an oversized casino, a music level, and a comic book world. A fan suggestion of a 'Yoshi School' was also met with interest.
Performance is a key consideration. Kaze rejected a potential background implementation specifically because the texture overdraw would be too demanding on the N64 hardware.
development_findings.quote: if you do that you are getting four times overdraw... so that would suck.

development_findings.summary: Kaze identified and fixed a graphical bug where lava bubble particles were rendering inside a pipe, tracing it to code that was using undefined vertices.
The retro levels are themed around games from the N64 era or earlier. Planned levels include inspirations from Smash 64, Mario Paint, Dr. Mario, and Super Mario Land.

context_findings.summary: Kaze has a pragmatic, almost cynical view of self-promotion, admitting to 'cloud chasing' but framing it as an honest character flaw rather than something to be disguised.
context_findings.quote: Dude, do you think being honest about being a cloud chaser makes being a cloud chaser less bad? Because I don't subscribe to cloud chasers. I'm just a piece of shit.

context_findings.summary: Kaze holds strong, sometimes controversial opinions on popular media, stating he finds Studio Ghibli films boring and Lego Fortnite 'miserable'.
context_findings.quote: I think Studio Ghibli movies are kinda really just very boring. Don't like them at all.

context_findings.summary: Kaze and his wife, Zeina, recently moved into a new house which includes a large home gym setup that he showed on stream.
Kaze prioritizes player experience and intuitive design over demonstrating technical capability, rejecting a level layout idea that, while possible, would likely confuse the player.
context_findings.quote: I feel like that would ruin gameplay... That's why I'm against it, not because of technical reasons.

context_findings.summary: Kaze works a full-time job at 'Gears for Breakfast' and mentions that if he didn't, he would have time for larger side projects like creating a supercut of his work.
Kaze values precision and conciseness in communication, a principle that extends to his philosophy on writing and, by extension, game design.
context_findings.quote: I think that when you speak you should be precise and you should be concise those are the two qualities i value the most in speech.

biobak.summary: Biobak was present in the stream's chat, but no specific contributions or collaborations involving him were discussed during this session.

badub.summary: Badub, the composer, has already completed the music for the levels currently in development, and Kaze holds the work in high regard.
badub.quote: We already have songs for all these areas from Badub. And the songs are a banger.

zeina.summary: Zeina was present in the chat and her presence was noted by Kaze. He mentioned they recently moved to a new house together and that he watched a movie with her.
Kaze lightheartedly integrates his relationship with Zeina into the stream, making her presence a condition for a specific channel point redemption.
zeina.quote: There has to be a stipulation that you can only get it while Zeina is here.

key_stories.title: The Smash 64 Background Recreation
key_stories.summary: Kaze struggled to recreate the Smash 64 background, with his initial attempt failing. He had a 'breakthrough' moment and decided to model large spheres and essentially 'cut out' the background shapes from their textures, resulting in a high-quality, performant, and dynamic 3D version of the classic backdrop.
key_stories.challenge: Recreating the iconic, layered 2D background from Super Smash 64's 'Board the Platforms' stage in 3D without destroying performance or looking cheap.
key_stories.process: Kaze's first attempt using many individual transparent squares failed visually, which he called 'terrible'. He then pivoted to a completely new idea: creating three large, high-poly spheres, drawing the background shapes onto them as textures in Blender, and then deleting the empty space. This created three distinct, layered skyboxes.
key_stories.outcome: The new method was a success, creating a visually impressive, high-quality version of the original background that Kaze was very happy with. He further enhanced it by adding a slow, multi-directional rotation to the layers.
key_stories.key_quote: I have THE idea. The best one yet... We will make a UV sphere... We're just gonna draw the shapes onto here.

key_stories.title: Live-Coding Camera Feedback
key_stories.summary: After receiving viewer feedback about the camera controls, Kaze explained his design goals and then live-coded a solution. He adjusted the camera's acceleration curve to better balance the needs of players making small, precise adjustments and those using it for broader movements.
key_stories.challenge: A viewer provided feedback that the d-pad camera controls were not good for small, precise adjustments because of the built-in acceleration.
key_stories.process: Kaze first explained the design philosophy behind the camera: it needed to serve both precise and casual players. Acknowledging the feedback, he then opened the code and live-edited the camera's movement curve, tweaking values to find a better balance between the two use cases.
key_stories.outcome: He implemented and tested new acceleration and velocity values on-stream, arriving at a compromise he felt was better. This new setting allows for small, tap-based adjustments while still functioning as a smooth rotational control for players who prefer it.
key_stories.key_quote: By making it have a bit of a velocity, you can do a minimal adjustment like this, but you can also use this as your main camera button. That's what I want, honestly.

open_questions.context: Kaze brainstormed several future level themes (Wild West, Casino, Music, Comic Book) but admitted to having 'no ideas' for the casino and music levels. He seemed intrigued by a fan's 'Yoshi School' suggestion.
